confession.devil_appearance: tall black man, with paws and claws
confession.seduction_context: The maire of Mandray, Claude Gabourel (later executed for robbery), was levying 'gros rancons' and seized her only cow, which she could not recover despite desperate pleas. On way in despair to Le Paire where her husband was ploughing land from her dowry, met the devil who promised to give her sufficient money after she explained her woes. She did not believe him at first. Scene repeated 2 or 3 days later on same spot, and this time she yielded, but 'money' he gave her wrapped in leaves turned out to be 'fiente de cheval' (horse dung).
powder_types: red powder to kill people or make them ill
grey powder to kill people or make them ill

witnesses.name: Mengeon Dion
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor, his wife was executed as witch 12 years earlier

testimony.quarrel_subject: quarrel between accused and her father

witnesses.name: Jehennon femme Colas Henry Finance
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: daughter of Catherine (executed witch who named accused)

witnesses.name: Claude Colin Mengeon
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor, stepson of accused (via his mother remarrying accused's husband)

witnesses.name: Didier Henry
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor, had legal dispute with accused's stepson

testimony.quarrel_subject: legal dispute 5 or 6 years before over a foal injured by Jennon's stepson with an iron fork; took husband to court at Mandray, he was condemned to pay 15 ecus and take foal, or 2 ecus for the wound. Took latter option.

witnesses.name: Claude Mathis
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: husband (current husband, married after first wife died)

testimony.quarrel_subject: He refused to join her husband in collecting tithes, which latter feared would be at a loss. His first wife advised him to do so after accused told her 'qu'il ne leur yroit pas bien' if he failed to do so.
testimony.threat_quote: qu'il ne leur yroit pas bien

harms_alleged.target_relationship: leased to Claudatte veuve Colin Mengin
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 5 or 6 years earlier, died in 8 days after Jennon remarked 'une bien belle vache'

testimony.quarrel_subject: His wife was 'indiscreet' and he had to beat her to 'teach' her. Accused counseled his wife to flee the house when beaten, cry alarm, take her clothes, and take refuge at accused's house, which she did repeatedly. He would fetch her back with blows of a stick.

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: later, after wife confessed she believed accused wanted to seduce her and make her a witch like herself

testimony.quarrel_subject: More than 7 years earlier her husband had called Jennon witch one evening, threatening to have her burned; she had also called her witch.
Lawsuit some 2 years before between her husband and husband of accused about a hedge between their fields.

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: After settlement of lawsuit, she went to ask to dry oats in accused's oven. Accused remarked it was a novelty to see the boy in her house. As he left he was shaking his head as if he had lost his wits, then went home singing and shouting in street. Soon afterwards when near her house he fell and got a splinter driven into his hand, and was ill for 8 days until he died, his hand clenched and twisted.

timeline.subject: Jennon Mengin
timeline.details: First interrogation, she denies all charges

timeline.subject: Jennon Mengin
timeline.details: Confronted with witnesses, makes no objections; judges think she wants to confess but will not yield

timeline.subject: Jennon Mengin
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves question ordinaire et extraordinaire, although latter not asked for

timeline.subject: Jennon Mengin
timeline.details: After being shaved and prepared for torture, she started to confess. Briefly racked to secure full confession about death of small son of Didier Henry.

timeline.subject: Jennon Mengin
timeline.details: Confirmed earlier confessions, added more accomplices

timeline.subject: Jennon Mengin
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine (wife of Mengeon Dion)
notable_quotes.context: What Catherine told her husband about Jennon 12 years before Catherine's execution

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Mengin
notable_quotes.french: il n'y avoit encor heu aucune Sorciere en son parenté, et que s'il en y avoit une, il falloit avoir patience
notable_quotes.english: there had never been any witch in her family, and if there was one, one must have patience
notable_quotes.context: Response when told that Catherine (being executed) had named her as accomplice, 12 years earlier

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Mengin (stepson)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il ne vouloit point manger de sa cuisine
notable_quotes.english: that he did not want to eat her cooking
notable_quotes.context: What stepson said about accused after an illness 4 or 5 years before

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Mengin
notable_quotes.french: qu'il ne falloit que trois tesmoings pour fournir a une information
notable_quotes.english: that it only took three witnesses to furnish information [for a trial]
notable_quotes.context: Overheard by neighbor after confrontation with Marguitte, when she was thinking of flight; husband corrected her saying it took many more

notable_quotes.speaker: Claude Mathis (via his first wife)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il ne leur yroit pas bien
notable_quotes.english: that it would not go well for them
notable_quotes.context: Threat/warning from accused if Claude Mathis failed to join her husband in collecting tithes

notable_quotes.speaker: Marion (first wife of Jean Bertremin)
notable_quotes.context: What Marion always told her husband about accused

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonne (wife of Mengeon Henry, via her confession)
notable_quotes.french: parmy les conseils d'icelle prevenue, elle avoit envye de la seduire, et rendre sorciere comme elle
notable_quotes.english: through the counsels of the accused, she had desire to seduce her and make her a witch like herself
notable_quotes.context: What the wife confessed to her husband after accused had counseled her to flee when beaten

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Mengin
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle le scavoit bien et qu'on le disoit partout
notable_quotes.english: that she knew it well and that people said it everywhere
notable_quotes.context: Response when told that Dieudonne suspected her of making the young son mad

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Mengin
notable_quotes.french: qu'il falloit laisser parler les gens, et qui vivroit verroit
notable_quotes.english: that one must let people talk, and whoever lives will see
notable_quotes.context: Response when told that Dieudonne had called her witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Mengin
notable_quotes.french: Jesus Maria, n'est ce que je ne scay
notable_quotes.english: Jesus Maria, is it not that I do not know
notable_quotes.context: Repeated several times when asked about episode with broomstick during interrogation

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Mengin
notable_quotes.french: depuis l'heure de sa tentation, elle n'a jamais eu bien, et toutes les fois qu'elle voioit mener a l'execution d'autres ses semblables ou oyoit parler de telle crime, elle avoit ung grand remort de conscience
notable_quotes.english: since the hour of her temptation, she never had good fortune, and every time she saw others like herself led to execution or heard talk of such crime, she had great remorse of conscience

relationships.evidence_text: wife of Claude Mengin of Fouchifol, laboureur
Daughter of Colas Masson of Anozel
First husband was Colas du Paire, of Le Paire de Sainte Margarée
His wife Catherine had been executed as witch 12 years earlier
On day of her mother Catherine's execution
his first wife Marion, his feue femme
Claude Mathis testified as husband of accused (current husband)
As close neighbour had heard her complaining
accused visited Marion frequently and familiarly in their house

economic_context.details: The trial reveals significant economic hardship at the time of seduction. Claude Gabourel, maire of Mandray (later executed for robbery), was levying 'gros rancons' and seized Jennon's only cow, which she could not recover despite desperate pleas. She only had one cow whose milk was for her small daughter from first marriage. This economic desperation precipitated her alleged pact with the devil. There were also property disputes: lawsuit about hedge between fields (witness 12), and dispute over injured foal that went to court at Mandray (witness 6). Witness 8 mentions tithes collection.

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: owned by witness and his mother
harms_catalog.harm_description: fine sow worth 12 francs became strangely ill, not eating, jumping to roof of stable, yet not dying. Recovered briefly after eating oats from accused's house, then died a few days later.
mare was carrying foal, but was only saved when witness and neighbours pulled it from her dead
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Legal dispute 5 or 6 years before: witness's foal was injured by Jennon's stepson with an iron fork; took her husband to court at Mandray, and he was condemned to pay 15 ecus and take foal, or 2 ecus for the wound. Took latter option.

harms_catalog.harm_description: After witness chased off accused's stepson's piglets from sucking from his sow, the sow lost her milk, so that 2 of her 5 piglets died.
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: chased off piglets belonging to accused's stepson

harms_catalog.harm_description: Wife died suddenly in 24 hours. She had always feared accused greatly.
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: perhaps disdain that they did not grant what accused requested
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft due to too great familiarity in their house

harms_catalog.victim_name: four children of Jean Bertremin and Marion
harms_catalog.harm_description: None of their four children survived, 3 died very quickly, one lived to be 4 or 5
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: perhaps disdain that they did not grant what accused requested
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft due to too great familiarity in their house

harms_catalog.victim_name: cow (leased to Claudatte veuve Colin Mengin)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Jennon remarked to witness that Claudatte had 'une bien belle vache', and it died in 8 days
His first wife Claudatte had feared her greatly, and had suspected her of causing her fatal illness
Lost a mare, which he had to sell for 2 francs for the leather
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: He refused to join her husband in collecting tithes; accused told his first wife 'qu'il ne leur yroit pas bien' if he failed to do so

harms_catalog.harm_description: His wife later died; did not know if Jennon was responsible, but wife had great fear and horror of her. Wife had confessed she believed accused wanted to seduce her and make her a witch like herself.
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Accused counseled wife to flee when beaten, take refuge at accused's house

harms_catalog.victim_name: cow (leased to Claudatte veuve Colin Mengin)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Believed accused killed cow after witness and her husband called accused witch
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: More than 7 years earlier her husband had called Jennon witch one evening, threatening to have her burned; witness had also called her witch.

harms_catalog.harm_description: Son's pig became ill, gave it oats after accused suggested this, and it died

harms_catalog.victim_name: small son of Didier Henry and Mengette
harms_catalog.harm_description: After lawsuit settlement, witness took her small son when she went to Jennon's house to ask if she could dry oats in their oven. Accused remarked it was a novelty to see the boy in her house. As he left he was shaking his head as if he had lost his wits, then went home singing and shouting in street. Soon afterwards when near her house he fell and got a splinter driven into his hand, and was ill for 8 days until he died, his hand clenched and twisted.
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Lawsuit some 2 years before between her husband and husband of accused about a hedge between their fields
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft after remarking on boy's presence, causing madness then death

harms_catalog.victim_name: young son of Mengeon Henry and Dieudonne
harms_catalog.harm_description: Dieudonne suspected Jennon of making her young son mad, went to accused's house to tell her so
Tried out powder on a calf and a pig of her own, which both died
Confessed to killing Marion by making poisoned soup with her accomplices, solely on orders of their master
Confessed to killing cow because Claudatte Mengin, to whom it was leased, often came to house and stole things
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Claudatte often came to house and stole things

harms_catalog.harm_description: Briefly racked to secure full confession about death of small son of Didier Henry - not clear whether she was refusing to make this. No motive given - some suggestion that this was again her master's doing.

accused only had one cow whose milk was for daughter
mare sold for only 2 francs for the leather

prior_legal_disputes.description: Church court at St. Dié over promise of marriage to Jeandel d'Anould; released when she swore her parents had not given consent. Accused of lying about this.
Legal dispute 5 or 6 years before over foal injured by Jennon's stepson with iron fork. Didier Henry took accused's husband to court at Mandray.
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Husband condemned to pay 15 ecus and take foal, or 2 ecus for the wound. Took latter option.

prior_legal_disputes.description: Lawsuit some 2 years before between Didier Henry (witness 6) and husband of accused about a hedge between their fields.

legal_context.redress_outcome: Accused took no action to secure reparation after being called witch publicly by Claudatte veuve Colin Mengin and her husband more than 7 years earlier
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: After confrontations on July 8, judges threatened to place her in a more obscure prison; she begged to be left where she was. She was frightened to return to prison where she might be beaten by her master; had previously been beaten for taking sacraments and refusing to bring host to him.

he had called her witch, and that her husband 'se mesfioit aussy d'elle'

about occasion when accused left house saying 'qu'elle s'en alloit au diable'
accused had sworn falsely in court at St. Dié against another who wanted to marry her

hearsay_chains.source: Dieudonne, late wife of Mengeon Henry
hearsay_chains.content: she suspected Jennon of making her young son mad, had gone to accused's house to tell her so

Made no objections to witnesses during confrontation
Judges thought she wanted to confess but would not yield (July 8)
Begged to be left in current prison rather than moved to more obscure one

After being shaved and prepared for torture, started to confess

Expressed remorse: 'depuis l'heure de sa tentation, elle n'a jamais eu bien, et toutes les fois qu'elle voioit mener a l'execution d'autres ses semblables ou oyoit parler de telle crime, elle avoit ung grand remort de conscience'
Frightened to return to prison where she might be beaten by her master

extraction_metadata.notes: This trial shows a woman with a long-standing reputation (12+ years) who was finally brought to trial. Key uncertainties: (1) The exact relationship between Claude Colin Mengeon (witness 4) and the accused is complex - he mentions 'her husband's son Claudon Mengin' suggesting he may be related through remarriage. (2) The identity of 'Bon Didier' as accomplice may be an alias. (3) Economic status assessed as 'poor' based on: only had one cow whose milk was for daughter, cow seized and could not recover it, desperate economic circumstances precipitating alleged pact. (4) Confession came after preparation for torture and brief racking - judges noted she was on point of confession before torture. (5) Multiple prior accusations but never acted on until this trial. (6) Strong pattern of harms following quarrels or legal disputes. (7) Accused showed hesitation about naming wife of Mengeon Masson, expressing desire not to accuse wrongly. (8) Notable that several witnesses were family members or close neighbors with complex relationships.
